factoid: The Mason says that Pierre hates something.
The Mason instructs Pierre to change that thing and purify himself.
The Mason says that as Pierre is purified, Pierre will gain wisdom.
The Mason tells Pierre to look at his life.
The Mason asks Pierre how he has spent his life.
The Mason says that Pierre has spent his life in riotous orgies and debauchery, receiving everything from society and giving nothing in return.
The Mason says that Pierre has become the possessor of wealth.
The Mason asks Pierre how he has used his wealth.
The Mason asks Pierre what he has done for his neighbor.
The Mason asks Pierre whether he has ever thought of his tens of thousands of slaves.
The Mason asks Pierre whether he has helped his slaves physically and morally.
The Mason says that Pierre has profited from the toil of his slaves to lead a profligate life.
The Mason says that Pierre has spent his life in idleness.
The Mason says that Pierre married a young woman and took on responsibility for her guidance.
The Mason says that Pierre has not helped his wife find the way of truth, but has thrust her into an abyss of deceit and misery.
The Mason says that a man offended Pierre and Pierre shot him.
The Mason says that Pierre says he does not know God and hates his life.
The Mason says that there is nothing strange in that.
After speaking, the Mason leans his arms on the back of the sofa and closes his eyes.
Pierre looks at the Mason's aged, stern, motionless, almost lifeless face and moves his lips without uttering a sound.
Pierre wishes to say "Yes, a vile, idle, vicious life!" but does not break the silence.
The Mason clears his throat huskily and calls his servant.
The Mason asks the servant how about the horses.
The servant answers that the exchange horses have just come.
The servant asks Pierre if he will not rest here.
Pierre thinks that the Mason might be leaving him alone without telling him all and without promising to help him.
Pierre says that he has never thought of it but has led a contemptible and profligate life, though he did not like it and did not want to.
Pierre says that the Mason knows the truth and, if he wished to, could disclose it to him.
Pierre wishes to say this to the Mason but does not dare.
The traveler Pierre packs his things with practiced hands and begins fastening his coat.
Pierre turns to Bezúkhov and asks where he is going now.
Bezúkhov replies that he is going to Petersburg.
Pierre thanks Bezúkhov and agrees with all he has said.
Pierre says that he should not be considered bad, and with his whole soul he wishes to be what the Mason would have him be.
Pierre says that he has never had help from anyone.
Pierre says that he is to blame for everything.
Pierre asks for help, teaching, and hopes to perhaps succeed.
The Mason remains silent for a long time, evidently considering.
The Mason says that help comes from God alone, but such measure of help as their Order can bestow will render Pierre.
The Mason says that Pierre is going to Petersburg and instructs him to hand a note to Count Willarski.
The Mason takes out his notebook and writes a few words on a large sheet of paper folded in four.
The Mason says that when Pierre reaches the capital, he should devote time to solitude and self-examination and not resume his former way of life.
The Mason wishes Pierre a good journey and success.
